title: Visitor Responses
publication_title: The Modern Series at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Over the course of Shattter Rupture Break the Art Institute of Chicago engaged the consulting firm Peacock Nine to gauge visitor experience of the exhibition. The responses below come from a two-part qualitative study that included a focus group whose participants visited the exhibition in addition to the modern art galleries on the third floor of the museum’s Modern Wing, as well as nearly one hundred qualitative intercepts, in which visitors were observed while inside Shatter Rupture Break and interviewed after leaving the exhibition.

In their questions the interviewers focused on visitors’ understanding of the overall theme of the exhibition; the time spent in the galleries; areas of engagement and interactivity; the clarity of exhibition materials; potential barriers or impediments; experiences that were appealing, confusing, or unappealing; and thoughts about the exhibition within the larger context the permanent-collection galleries of Art Institute of Chicago.

Below is a selection of visitors’reactions in their own words.

“It was amazing being upstairs [in the permanent collection galleries]. Picasso?! That was crazy! . . . But to me, that was the extent of the conversation. It was like, ‘Picasso, you know him? He did this.’ Downstairs [in Shatter Rupture Break] it was more ‘Why? What encouraged it? What inspired it?’”

“On the third floor [in the permanent collection galleries] you are surrounded by these big names and I felt like, ‘Wow, this is cool’ . . . but down here [in Shatter Rupture Break], it was like ‘These people are crazy . . . and it’s awesome.’”

“I wanted to get the hell out of there.”

“I felt like I was in the Wizard of Oz or something.”

“There was so much stimulation going on that I felt, not panic . . . but [tension].”

“It was very dark and gloomy . . . I loved that.”

“It was ‘darker’ . . . I felt like it was more desperate feeling. I don’t know if I necessarily think that it was bad, the more that I walked around . . . but it didn’t feel like a happy place to me.”

“It felt a little on edge . . . I was drawn in by the film. It’s a little different. Then I thought, ‘What were they trying to do here?’ I read the sign that talked about fragmenting and how they would take the teeth and blow them up on the screen and that was more interesting than just the normal size of the mouth on the screen. I thought it was really interesting. I really liked it.”

“I felt like I really needed to read the plaques, because I was confused by what it was at first.”

“I found it less beautiful and for me a bit more important. It’s about creating art and arts placed in the face of technology or in industrial revolution, things are moving faster than art could keep up with and I read a lot of poetry [from the] turn of the century about all the anxiety that artists were feeling at the time and the fragmentation, postmodernism.”

“I was ‘weirded out’ by the video . . . the eyeballs, the legs and feet flipping upside down . . . but that was the intent. It was a frenetic period. That’s why it is hard to feel very serene in the space.”

“I thought it was really interesting . . . I love the idea of changing in our culture at the turn of the century into the 20th century as it is now. It makes you feel kind of uneasy.”

“It felt like [Shatter Rupture Break] was different—like it was shattering the norm.”

“[Shatter Rupture Break] was less traditional. . . . It's not just one thing over and over and over and over again. It breaks things up so there’s multiple things for your eye to focus on.”

“If I was going to pick out a piece of art for my place, I’d take one from the third floor gallery—but if you want an experience that you’ve never had before, or if you want to learn something, I would go for [Shatter Rupture Break] personally.”

“It made me feel like the students at the SAIC [the School of the Art Institute of Chicago] might have curated all of those pieces.”

“I think that a younger crowd would have liked the first floor exhibit.”

“I think [the Art Institute] would get a younger crowd with [Shatter Rupture Break].”

“[Shatter Rupture Break] you know, just being [left to act like] an adult in that place . . . no ‘don’t touch that’ [feeling]. I think [that’s] because they wanted you to feel that craziness of [it firsthand]. The ‘Oh, my God. It’s so close. I can like [almost touch it]’ . . . I wanted to touch that chair so badly because there were no barriers telling me not to [touch it], do know what I mean? Then I was just like, ‘Go everywhere. Just run around.’ And that’s just what I did!”

“The first floor gallery [Shatter Rupture Break] was more engaging [than the permanent collection galleries].”

“[Shatter Rupture Break] was more entertaining.”

“I will say the first floor was a lot more engaging, regardless of the art there. It was a lot more engaging in terms of finding out about the art, because of the quotes it was like a lot more interactive. They had quotes around the descriptions and it was more verbal discussion of what was happening rather than just a translation. It was a bigger font and it just felt more interactive and easier to understand.”

“I think that [Shatter Rupture Break] could teach the third floor something [about interactivity] . . . Maybe it is something as simple as adding social media or check-in spots, or something.”

“I felt enveloped by this form that I am not familiar with. That was a good thing.”

“That sense of flow [appealed to me].”

“You’re not sure where to go.”

“It wasn’t a traditional square.”

“It’s really nice to see how you guys used the partitions in the space this time.”

“The way that it was set up . . . with the walls in between . . . there were angles that made you want to explore more.”

“I think that within that exhibit the experience worked perfectly. It would have felt super-weird if I had to go down a set path in that first floor gallery.”

“On the third floor [permanent-collection galleries of the Modern Wing] you could stand in the corner and see everything. In [Shatter Rupture Break] you really had to keep moving and explore a little bit more to see what was coming up next—which I thought was interesting. It was a good flow.”

“The way [Shatter Rupture Break] was set up with the walls in between and angles . . . it made you want to explore more and see what [comes next].”

“Sitting by the film was very disquieting . . . I couldn’t even handle it. I couldn’t even look at it anymore.”

“I will say that I was mesmerized by the whole crazy of that video. Also, the way I took it is that art doesn’t have to be beautiful. Some of the stuff you write on the wall it pretty much said that you can paint with a Band-Aid or at least with a bunch of things you can paint with and it [can] still be art. To me that’s what I took from it.”

“The video inspired me. It made me feel more creative.”

“The films were different . . . very modern to me.”

“I loved reading the quotes . . . it made me feel more . . . more goose bumps.”

“[The quotes] give you a better feel of what the artist was understanding when they did it.”

“It was more of a conversation rather than just ‘I’m telling you like it is’ . . . It is a much more interactive way to find out more about the art.”

“The one [quote] was almost like reading a love letter.”

“[The quotes] made it feel much more intimate . . . more personal.”

“The quotes make it feel more personal.”

“I like the quotes. They really worked for me . . . It made me think about [what] Georgia O’Keeffe was thinking about when these pictures were taken. How she felt about being the model for these things. For example, when she said, ‘You know, everyone always compliments me on my hands.’ I thought, that’s kind of interesting, something I didn’t know about Georgia O'Keeffe. I thought that the pictures were beautiful, but I didn’t know how to measure the pictures.”

“I really liked getting a perspective from the artists themselves, their words, what they’re saying, what they’re thinking, what their thought process was rather than a description from a student or an academic . . . I felt more connected.”

“The quotes made me understand that some people don’t necessarily see art as something that’s beautiful . . . that some people make art from pain. That’s what I got from the wall quotes.”

“No, I didn’t see any paper.”

“I took the brochure because I wanted to learn more . . . I read some of it in there. I will use it as a reference.”

“I grabbed [the brochure] at the end, when I left, because I thought ‘I need to remember a lot of stuff from in here.’”

“I like the thematic [approach]. It is nice to see the thematic [approach] rather than just the artist . . . Do a thematic idea and then bring a lot of artists, a lot of works, together.”

“I like the mix of different kinds of objects or mediums presented.”

“During this time, we weren’t just painting or drawing. We were doing a lot of experimentation in film, and different aspects. It’s important to have all those together . . . I need all of those things.”

“This is less traditional—and more interesting, I guess . . . It isn’t just one thing over and over and over and over again. It breaks things up—there are multiple things for your eye to focus on.”

“The sound engaged me right away.”

“The sound . . . it grabbed me.”

“It made me feel like ‘holy shit . . . here we go!’”

“Initially, I found the audio to be a little too loud upon first entering the space—but then, with the other two films it was fine.”

“It was powerful.”

“It transported me.”

“I felt desperation.”

“It definitely set the tone.”

“The audio in the back [of the exhibit] grabbed me . . . I could just sit there and listen. It made me imagine this guy . . . in his old school boots . . . . It [transported] me there.”

“[Shatter Rupture Break] felt depressing at first . . . It took me back to Berlin or bad time East Germany, post-Holocaust . . . that’s where I first went when I heard the music.”

“The write-ups I thought were very good. The introduction, I think this piece was nicely done.”

“We often feel this need to have things described to us. I think that this exhibit . . . was refreshing because you could define it on your own terms and enjoy it without being, ‘Okay, this is a textile from . . . blah, blah, blah.’”

“I think I would be distracted, completely . . . if [the description were] right next to the work. I would be reading about [the work] first, and then I would be looking at the work. I wouldn’t be getting a first impression.”

“I like timelines . . . . A timeline [would have been useful]. I wasn’t quite sure what time period were we thinking [about here]. [I’d like to] see the painting in a particular timeline . . . Cubism . . . Surrealism . . . when was this all happening?”

“The only other suggestion that I was thinking about, when I was walking through [Shatter Rupture Break], is that the pieces tend to look at this disruption or rupture from particular sorts of lens, right? We didn’t necessarily see people who had been involved in that content of Africa or from the Middle East or from the Americas . . . . Was this only an American phenomenon?”

“Show the art of women globally. Even the U.S. there’s so little of that but also we don’t think of it globally. We think of art as still very male.”

“They asked you to send feedback via an email to info@artinstitute.com . . . It was hard to follow suit on that unless it was a QR code or a survey that you could send back right away . . . rather than typing out an email address.”

</section>
